column123: Misogyny seems to be in resonance. Women's career advancement is stalling because men think that women have achieved equality. Many do not wish to be involved in further efforts as they see them discriminatory to males. column123: I have never been paid as much as comparable males (initially) in any position I have held. In one position I supported a man getting a salary for a position I eventually aspired to which annoyed my boss. When I applied for the position (exactly the same qualifications more experience) I was reluctantly offered it at a lower salary. I refused it on that basis. The man (who had gained promotion did not support my position as I had his because he didn't want to get off-side with the boss as I had on his behalf. He has had a lucrative career supported by that same boss in another organisation. In my current position I was assessed at a lower salary than younger male (unqualified) employees as my qualifications are now seen as obsolete. In my first professional role after gaining a postgrad degree I was paid less than half the similarly qualified men for the same work. The Director, when asked, told me he knew I was on the DPB when I applied for the role and he assumed I would work for slightly less (he was right although I did not know at the time the other salaries in the organisation.

column204: I think our organisation does a lot of really great work to promote women, and I think we're probably one of the best in New Zealand. I think keeping on embedding the good things being done, and normalising diversity in the workplace so it stops being seen as a niche consideration, or as just a women's thing. I think our CE has been very strong in emphasizing that promoting women is a job for everyone, not just women.  I think we need to keep normalising flexible working arrangements (instead of it being unusual, or a hindrance), normalising different perspectives and using "womanly" traits (e.g. more emotions in the workplace, more consensus building behaviours).  Lastly, I think we need to start calling out unhelpful behaviours and attitudes - e.g. addressing why it's still overwhelmingly women who clean the kitchen areas at work, and do catering for work events.
column208: I'd struggle to believe there's many organisations out there with better diversity policies and practices than ours (outside of diversity-advocacy groups).
column210: It would lift the visibility of the role of women and diversity in our workplace, help normalise women in senior roles, and help us position our organisation as being a leading, forward place to work. Our organisation is a good one, but even our leadership figures acknowledge it's not great when the leadership team is all white men, and one white woman. They might have the best of intentions, and be very good, talented, decent human beings, but they cannot possibly represent diversity to the extent that an actually diverse leadership would be able to.
column211: I do a lot of biographies of people for business meetings (for my boss). column56: The HR market in Wellington is ridiculously competitive. In the last six months, I have been interviewing like crazy and have made it to #2 preferred candidate in 9 separate selection processes. Incredibly frustrating to be so close but so far. These experiences have led me to revaluate where I'm going in my career and to take a lateral move, which will hopefully pay off in the future.
column69: My husband and I try to share things, but as he has a serious medical condition - there's a lot of things he can't manage. I still tend to do the most part of household chores.
column123: Yes, barriers do still exist. There are the traditional issues (i.e. women of childbearing age may take parental leave, so are overlooked during the recruitment process for certain roles), but I also think the 'Just Like Me' factor plays a large role in recruiting for HR Advisor roles here in Wellington. We are starting to build a community of likeminded HR practitioners here in Wellington via HRINZ, APP and also the new Wellington HR Meet-Up group - but it can be a wee bit tricky to develop relationships in the sector, as we do have a tendency to be a bit 'cliquey' at times. I've definitely struggled to feel confident in networking with other HR Practitioners, particularly when I'm a junior and haven't had exposure to the depth of issues that senior colleagues have.
column187: I landed my first 'proper HR job' at 29, which is quite late for entry-level HR people. Prior to that, I'd worked in HR-aligned roles such as recruitment. Because I've not had much in the way of mentoring or formal development opportunities (aside from the ones I've sought myself), I feel like my professional development has been impaired.

column190: I'm starting to see that over the years, I've built up a tremendous amount of 'soft skills', in addition to my technical abilities. Am looking at the possibility of specialising in Employment Relations or maybe moving into the Health and Safety space.

column190: Your survey is targeted towards ONLY women in organisations.  / Why not say that right at the beginning? I gave up halfway as most of the questions weren't relevant to me, but there was no option for me to reflect that. The questions aren't really well thought out from that perspective. What about all the women who do short term contract work? Many are in stand-alone positions like mine, and a great many now are doing portfolio work. Questions like these only make women feel demoralised about themselves when they are NOT in the positions that you imply with your questions:upwardly mobile in a large organisation. column123: YES. I have consistently seen less competent male employees at all levels of the organisation be given more opportunities to develop and progress. From what I've seen, this is partly because males tend to be more ego-driven and talk up their (no matter how minor) individualised achievements, while women tend to focus on teamwork and more sustained, genuine, but less visible achievements. Managers are suckers for self-promotion and simplistic, measurable, individualised 'results'. They tend not to value or see the less tangible but often more significant and sustained results that tend to come from women and teamwork.

column123: Yes. I work in community development which is generally perceived as soft skill and women's work. Despite this, several men work in my department and I notice that they are able to speak the language of infrastructure and outcomes etc etc, which means they are considered as more intelligent or able to navigate political processes than the women. Arguably the women understand the nature of community development, flexibility, patience, partnership etc etc far better but are not recognised for development or that they have a unique skill set. Community development is an interesting area because you have to be able to work at a grassroots level while also navigating political processes, but many of the people who 'succeed' can demonstrate the latter but are actually no good at the former..
column187: I am 23 years old and finished university when I was 20. column123: Yes and I feel the much of the focus is on how women should adapt themselves to fit into the current structure and ways of doing things so that they can overcome the barriers. However, I feel this will only ever advantage some individuals and will leave behind a much greater number of individuals, not just women, who do not fit the current model of leadership. The focus should instead be on removing the barriers and valuing the different ways that people work and lead. Things like implicit bias are very strong and while many people in influential positions are acknowledging its existence, they are not doing what is needed to counter it. The lack of visible diversity at senior levels in my organisation and messages around that to excuse it ('right people in the right places') also make it difficult to see that there is a place for women at senior levels in this organisation.

My career is my artistic & academic aspiration, which in part is funded by moneyjobs.  My moneyjobs are also so that I can partially or fully support other family members (my age and older) at any time now and in the future.   / I remember answering something about my job as "yes" for unpleasant and also "yes" as "I enjoy it - this may confuse researchers!!  I wanted to explain that I believe it is genuinely unpleasant (as it in indoors, unnarual environment, and away from my family for the best part of my energy-day!!) but I also *make my own fun* and end up enjoying this thing, because I *chose* to do it myself.  This is my theory of work.   / Happy to be interviewed although my situation my make categorization tricky. / Also worth noting as a woman:  I would probably have children or responsibility for children by now if I had been more economically successful.  Interesting to note!  Get the feeling it is the same for some peers. / All the best.

column123: There are still multiple barriers - many in terms of perceptions, rather than women's actual abilities or situation. I have had a successful career, but have adapted my goals to suit my own interests. At earlier stages, there were definite barriers to advancement due to family responsibilities (child, partner's illness). While much has changed there are still barriers, more in some organisations than others. Now, I definitely have the sense that age is a barrier, although I am committed to working for another 5-10 years. It is assumed that I won't be looking for career advancement at this stage of my life.  The window between being "too young" for opportunities or responsibility, or "too focused on family" or "too old" is pretty narrow!
column187: I was expected to go to secretarial college, get married and leave work to raise children, so I consider my career pretty successful. I have a PhD, have been a CE and have changed career direction a couple of times.I define success more in terms of doing things I'm interested in rather than a traditional career trajectory. And I do have male friends who have followed teh more traditional path who actually had a much smoother ride to the big salaries, simply because they were a better "fit". Nothing personal, but this does result in income discrepancies which still have a big impact on our lives. My ability to sustain a good standard of living in "retirement" will be impacted by that. There is a narrow window being being "too young", "too focused on family" and "too old". I think this is decreasing, but hopefully this study will contribute to that.

column123: Yes. I feel like there is an expectation to know what I want in the long term and to be able to commit now if I want a family or not. It seems impossible to be able to narrow down what opportunities for what are available for me where and doing it by myself is terrifying. The thought of leaving everything to travel would be amazing but I feel like I would be starting back at zero every time I moved or if I came back to "settle down". if I stay, I feel immense pressure to buy a house but only have myself to deal with all the housing issues. I would likely get flatmates to help with the money but dealing with long term planning and repairs and having the consistency and assured rental income would not be there.

column123: a number of organisations are traditionally geared towards men, eg manufacturing, science, engineering, pilots, regulators. I have worked in all of these areas and in the majority of cases was the only female senior manager until I managed to employ more women. (that didn't always happen) in my current organisation there is a very small number of female managers. no females on the board or on the senior leadership team. it is a long, and tedious uphill battle to try to redress the balance. the barriers are not just job related. for men who are over 60, there is frequently a version of what women do in their heads (not all but definitely the majority) and that is in a clerical role or teacher/nurse

column123: I think some are self-imposed because women, in general, may "seek balance" in life more than men. In many cases, this might stem from a greater feeling of guilt about separation from family responsibilities, rather than a genuine desire to be constantly active as parents / partners. I believe the pressure to be at home for the family every afternoon, purely to be 'present' consistently, means women get their work done efficiently but limit their own opportunities to stretch and develop skills if it means, by necessity, giving more time to work and not being physically present for their families occasionally.

column204: The organisation itself needs to offer training for future women leaders, but needs to focus more on junior staff as this is where ambition is born. Junior female staff are in greater need of assistance with developing their confidence, willingness to take personal risks, ability to network and push themselves forward. If motherhood proves to be limiting to a woman's advancement, it is all the more important to develop leadership skills and grow her ambition before motherhood becomes an issue in her career and she feels she must compromise her time.

column56: I came into the workforce in a really economically uncertain time. My concentration was on getting a job, and I didn't have much aspiration in mind beyond that given how difficult everyone made it sound to just get on the ladder.
column76: Perceptions of qualities that make candidates suitable for promotion. There is a tendency for loud, somewhat obnoxious men to be promoted at my workplace. Currently women make up 60 percent of my workplace, but only 24 percent of managers.
column123: I feel there are definitely barriers given men are so disproportionately represented in management positions. Only 25 percent of managers here are women, despite women making up 75 percent of the workplace. The men I have seen promoted tend to have bad personal skills. They get promoted into a people-management role, then actively and openly resent actually managing people. They complain about having to conduct performance reviews or have performance conversations and say they aren't important, and when our (female) senior managers basically forces them to, they say things like "[Female manager] is making us have this catch-up/meeting etc". I feel men are often successful because they are willing to boast about their achievements and women are. I have (unfortunately) seen female managers praise certain men's mediocre work very highly for no apparent reason, but I never hear managers praise female workers, even when their work is of a very high standard. I feel like the people who tend to become managers at my work are often simply the most extroverted person in the room.
column187: I do think, considering I've only been in the workforce for 18 months, my career has gone well. I'm earning a good 10k more than what I expected to be earning at this stage, and I have mentors who have created opportunities for me to learn and stretch myself at work. What I question though is how successful I'll be in applying for more senior positions that bring with them higher salaries. I get given opportunities that normally managers/much more senior people would take on, which in one way is great but at the other day, given I ultimately come to work to be paid, can be frustrating when at performance review time my direct manager seems reluctant to even have a performance review, let alone have a meaningful conversation about what I do. That appears to me to be what is stopping me from getting bigger payrises, as I'm never given areas to improve on. I have been disappointed at seeing highly qualified female candidates get passed over for vastly inferior male candidates, and I worry this will happen to me.
column189: I would like to move into a role where I have more autonomy and where I feel the work I'm doing is more meaningful (ie, works towards a cause I'm really passionate about in a more direct way than my current one). I will probably do an OE at some stage too.
column190: Ideally I will end up in some kind of management position, but I'm conscious of not rushing that step. I want to become a manager when I feel confident that I will be benefiting the work and people I'm supervising. Sometimes I feel like certain people apply for management positions because it benefits them in terms of salary, and don't care that they people they're supervising are struggling because of them. I wouldn't like to be that sort of manager.
column191: My career aspirations have been shaped by opportunities my mentors have given me, or that I've proactively taken on myself. I can see that I've earned respect from senior managers, as well as just bottom-of-the-rung staff like me, and that gives me confidence in my abilities.

column202: Equal recognition of achievement.
column204: I have taught in both co-ed and girls' schools throughout my career and the difference comes from the relationships, the opportunities provided and professional trust that exists. I have also seen what micro-managing can do and the effect on morale when things are not going well. /  / In teaching, admin need to look after their staff and provided support when needed. column208: I think there is a huge amount of sexism in the workplace and as a young female it is very difficult to witness. The number of male managers compared to females is disproportionate. Also the numerous times that managers have asked me do cleaning jobs is ridiculous and something that is never even suggested to my male colleagues. I have overheard comments from older male colleagues saying a certain younger female is the office was "nice to look at but didn't have a lot going on in her head". I have also seen an older male manager out of work context who told me he wanted to hire me because I was attractive. It is tiring and degrading and it made me not want to go back to work. In an ideal world I would have had my PhD and a role with a salary to match. I love my work and totally deliver in it but I also don't feel that the quality and outcomes I achieve gets the recognition it deserves. I see what others do and can see my results and outcomes far exceed the productivity of others in the same kind of work. I'm not quite sure what it is that I am doing wrong. column204: Support women to grow into leadership roles. Think differently about how to  define leadership. column208: I've had some amazingly positive experiences and really grown as a professional. I've had my fair share of working with people who are "managers " rather than "leaders"... it's not pleasant. Their achievements are mediocre at best and defined by the safety of achievement hampering process. Those are the people who put barriers in front of me. They dominate. I am so grateful to have escaped thst environment! !!!!
column210: I guess what I have discovered is that some people are really good at building relationships, listening to stakeholders and community and hearing people's voices before they decide how to identify value propositions or come up with solutions. / Those people are the ones who feel no need to bring their own egos into the process. Thst ego thing isn't gender specific. It's related to how a person defines their own value and the things they define as important. It requires relinquishing the nerd for power and control. I think men and women are equally at risk of bringing their egos to the table.  What is critical is the kind of culture you operate in. ... acknowledgment of one another strengths without fear around the need to compete with eachother.  / Women who thrive and reach the top tend to take two forms. ...women who survive by behaving like they perceive a man would and women who feel free to be themselves and are authentic to who they are as a person and adapt to the people they lead including the range of strengths they bring to the table. ... the same can be said of men. Because many organisation's are based around competition and ego,  it gets in the way of good leadership. And because men tend to dominate at the top and support competitive and ego driven leadership women struggle to get there. / I thrive under leadership that is not competitive or ego driven.

column211: As above - I don't think sexism is the issue.  It is the break in career to have kids, and then the reluctance to spend all your life at work that reduces the stats of women in management.  Schools don't get what it means to have 2 working parents, especially if the mother is the main earner - they still on the whole operate like there is a mum at home to get the kids organised.  That adds stress to kids and working mums - neither feel in control.  then school holidays come around....  the best thing to get more women in leadership is to increase the amount of annual leave they can take, enhance school holiday programmes in communities, and educate schools on how to support working mothers - better communication, less notices in bags (that get lost), less reliance on parents to help at school and do fundraising (increased guilt and pressure).  My view is the government need to fund support for working mothers - paid leave, school holiday programmes, and school funding.

column191: I am the sole earner for my household, and have been the primary earner for 20 years, for quite a while supporting my husband's former family also, and more recently my elderly father. No-one seems to consider that if a woman isn't a single parent, she could still have major financial responsibilities. So earning a decent salary is quite a strong motivator for me, and I have left jobs several times for better salaries when promised increases for outstanding performance didn't eventuate. Have also moved cities and countries to advance my career. But I have found it extremely hard to build a career in stepwise progress. I need intellectual challenge, have a technical background; also a Masters in business at my own expense, as my interests have developed. Have at times managed staff, but with each new role, it's as if I have to prove my credentials all over again. Now here I am in a rather junior role at this age. But of course I'm not tolerating that - have always sought to make my own opportunities when they don't arise naturally. Enjoy working with people, leading teams etc.
column204: Regrettably, this survey, though I commend it, is largely based on the presumption that the problem lies with women, rather than organisations - e.g. that capable women need role models, or lack confidence, or need "support".  / Some very practical changes need to be made, and social norms need to be changed, actively and deliberately.  / Since the 1970s, when it first began to matter to me, we have made almost no progress on on-site childcare. Imagine if we had that. How much happier and more productive would parents be if their preschoolers were cared for in the building (or nearby), and their older kids had onsite after-school and holiday care? / A great piece of research I read recently said that if interview candidates for a role included more than one capable woman (or person of minority ethnicity, etc) then it "normalized" the candidacy of women, and a woman was more likely to be chosen. (If the same capable woman was the only female candidate, she was never appointed, in this study.) HR practices should reflect this. Then as more women came through, this would be reflected at all levels of the organization. It is disgraceful that there are currently so few women in senior management in the public service. The approximate gender balance in individuals entering Govt organisations indicates that the absence of women at higher levels reflects ACTIVE choices being made to reject them. The explanation that women take time off to have children, adversely impacting their careers, is simply untrue for a very large number of women these days - and even those who do take parental leave take 1-2 years at most.
column210: Not a commercial organization. At least it couldn't hurt. I don't believe that women are inherently smarter, better organized etc than men - but it would be very motivating for women throughout the organization to see women reflected equally at the top. / For private sector organisations - emphatically yes. All the research shows that diversity in senior management results in better decision-making and therefore better commercial outcomes.

column211: I used to work in Hospital Pharmacy. One workplace I used to be at, I was asked to come to an interview with the boss to discuss my ongoing performance at work, because I was 'not pulling my weight', (I had clinical depression, and was not able to carry the slackers, basically!)- I had the unions help with this matter- The workplace I moved to was even worse, the boss treated people differently and some pharmacists could carry on with their own little projects which created career advancement, while I was involved with service provision that meant the background work got done.. the other colleague who got to do their own projects were males, by the way- After a disagreement with the boss, any chance at promotion was blocked. I left hospital pharmacy because I wasn't feeling valued by my colleagues- they would hold their meetings on the day I worked, so that I could have 'access' to current presentations, although one I did was perceived as 'unprofessional' - Others would be given study time at work to prepare presentations, I wasn't. The last straw was when I was given time to finish an assignment during work time, my own work that I normally was responsible for was not adequately covered, so that I had a double workload to come back to as well as three people's workload to cover in a busy lunch hour when everyone went to a meeting about a topic that I would have liked to be able to learn about too- I was apparently 'out of the loop' and was not offered an opportunity to attend such meeting- I paged 3 people to come back and help me and not one responded. This situation lasted for about an hour and a quarter- The response was ' We hope you finished your assignment OK' I quit! Since then I have only worked in situations that are safe working environments where I am not at the bottom of the pecking order or there is no perceived bullying culture. I go where I am celebrated, not just tolerated.

column123: Old boys network still unfortunately an issue. Men socialise more than woman executives and often tap into their network for staff. It's often stated as "who they feel they can work with best". Lack of job rotation a big one...senior male managers stay in their sometimes "cushy" role for many years. They become very stale but the organisation won't move them on. So  that reduces career opportunities. Often senior roles are appointed by someone on the boardsame via someone they know. Board positions are typically male dominated so the boys club mentally and hiring patterns continue. Bullying has been an issue in my career...I have stood up against this ...the HR department are aware and yet the person continues to be promoted. I've learnt HR departments are on a whole a complete waste of time in this country.

There was a recent article in the Herald where a businessman of 25+ years said that his experience is that women don't want to be 'promoted' they want stability and an income, but not the long hours, pressure etc that come with a senior role.  The article hinted that they are perhaps smarter than men, to go along earning money, not fighting it out, not getting stressed, just earning a wage.  He was harassed for the article which I think is unfair, as his comments carry the weight of experience and are therefore more valid and accurate than many other articles on the topic. /  / Progression is probably made harder for the women who do want to 'climb the ladder' because so many don't want to.  Which is a shame for them, but if they have the confidence and talent to succeed, then they probably will anyway.
